708303f-a.folder: 5th Avenue & Washington Square and 8th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
708303f-a.original_title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Square and 8th Street (West)

710986f-a.text:
4-6 and 8 West 8th Street, adjoining S.W. corner of Fifth Avenue. 4 and 6 used to be stables; the former is now the Clay Club Studio. No. 8, which is only partially included in the picture, is being remodelled to house the Whitney Museum of American Alrt. Compane this with the view of the whole block in May, 1933, two
years later.
March 21, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

710991f-a.text:
19-31 West 8th Street (formerly also known as Clinton Place), north side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues; part of the principal
small shop and restaurant street of the Village.
Marta's, shown at 23 West 8th Street, is a dancing restaurant, with
Spanish entertainers.
April 26, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  Niea w 5E2

710995f-a.text:
33-35 West 8th Street, north side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, showing two typical Village restaurants, Anne Miller's at 33 and The Bamboo Forest at 35. The Bamboo Forest, a Chinese place, took the premises over about 1932; its predecessor was a Japanese Restaurant.

April 26, 1933

P.L. Sperr
Neg # 555

710997f-a.text:
8th Street (formerly known also as Clinton Place), east from 47 West 8th Street, between Sixth and Fifth Avenues, showing the One Fifth Avenue apartment building (built about 1927) in the background. This is one of the principal small shop and restaurant centers of Greenwich Village. Alice McCollister's, shown at No. 3, is one of the best known restaurants, favored not only for dinner but also for late Sunday breakfast.
May 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

710993f-a.text:
(1)
33-25 West 8th Street, north side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, opposite the northern end of Macdougal Street.
May 26, 1934.

May 28, 1934.
P.L. Sperr.  No REPRODUCTIONS. Neg. #554

711000f-a.text:
West 8th Street, south side, west from Fifth Avenue to M.acdougal Street (right of View 1). -t the left are former stables of which the first (No.4) is the studio of the Clay
Club.
Adjoining the second of these is the whitney Musepm of Modern Art. This institution, founded by Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt,occupied the remodelled structures No's. 8-10-12, in 1931. View No. 2 shows only the huseui and its main entrance.
P. L. Sperr

708306f-a.text:
8 Fifth Avenue, at the S.W. corner of West 8th Street. This structure identified as the Marble House is a Rhinelander building.
February 1, 1938
Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project

708308f-a.text:
No's. 9 to 19 Fifth Avenue, at, adjoining and north of the N. E. corner of East 8th treet, showing prominently the cafe of the Hotel Brevoort. The Hotel is composed of three structures and which bear No's. 9 to 17 inclusive. Adjoining same is a four story basement dwelling with white window trim. This is No. 19 . At the left margin appears a portion of the Samuel Clemens(Mark Twain) house, located at the S. E. corner of East 9th Street. View No. 2 shows the canopied entrance to the Hotel and the American and French flags above same.
No. 1: August 16, 1933
2: July 16, 1938
P. L. Sperr

710988f.folder: 8th Street (West) btw University Place & 5th Avenue, Manhattan, NY
710988f.original_title: Manhattan: 8th Street (West) btw University Place - 5th Avenue

710972f.text:
15-13-11-9 East 8th Street (formerly 53-59 Clinton Place), north
side, east of Fifth Avenue.
13 East 8th Street (formerly 55 Clinton Place), the house with the large vine, has been for some years the home of Richard Watson Gilder, author and Editor-in-Chief (since 1881) of The Century Magazine who will continue to reside here till his death in 1909. Eighth Street, west of Broadway, used to be called Clinton Place, the houses being numbered west from Broadway. The name and numbering was changed in 1899. As may be seen in this picture, the street has already lost its residential character. Nearly thirty years later this scene will not have changed greatly. Mr. Giloer's house will have been remodelled like No. V; the parlor store will be occupied by Fred Leighton's Indian Trading Post, and the basement
by a gown shop and an interior decorator.
April 11, 1906.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCT1ONS.  MNeg N 6-2
